Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Opioid-Sparing Anesthesia in Laparoscopic Major Abdominal Surgery

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults aged 18-65 years undergoing laparoscopic major abdominal surgery.

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either remifentanil (Remi group, n=77) or esketamine combined with dexmedetomidine (OS group, n=80)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the numeric rating scale (NRS) pain score on postoperative day (POD)1.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated list, and allocation was concealed with opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Remi group, n=77 or esketamine combined with dexmedetomidine (OS group, n=80)

Result_Outcome.evidence: OS group had significantly lower NRS pain scores and a lower proportion of rescue analgesia compared to the Remi group (NRS: 1 vs 3, p=0.001; rescue analgesia: 5.0% vs 15.6%, p=0.028)

Harms.evidence: Extubation time was longer in the OS group (31 vs 20 minutes, p<0.01), and the proportion of dreaminess was higher (42.5% vs 15.6%, p<0.01).
